fields.description:
###Summary\\
Normal online text has conventions for how to enclose URLs so they are\\
correctly parsed in free-form text. The RFC 3986\\
[URL:https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986] describes the standard two\\
(with “[URL:%E2%80%9D%2C%E2%80%9C]”, and with “<”,“>”).

Bitbucket incorrectly parses URLs enclosed in this standard way; see [URL:https://bitbucket.org/wspdigital/benf_wspdigital-boc-my-agent-mobile-web/commits/fb69c40fdc03ea7b99dd5ec135f33a9e2c7f51ed] for an example. The HREF incorrectly includes the enclosing “>”, which makes Bitbucket link to an incorrect URL though the original text was correct.

###Steps to Reproduce

* Push a commit message with _[URL:http://....Link....]_
* Check the Bitbucket repository commit page

###Expected Results###\\
It displayed as _[URL:http://....Link....]_\\
The hyperlink includes '>' and redirect to _http://....Link....>_

###Actual Results###\\
It should be display as _....Link...._\\
The hyperlink will redirect to _http://....Link...._

###Notes###\\
Please correct the URL parsing to conform to the common conventions (described in RFC 3986) for URLs in the context of free-form text.

###Workaround###\\
None.

(Suggestions to “remove the markup” do not apply because these are messages written independent of Bitbucket, for a broader audience than Bitbucket, in a standard markup.)
fields.summary: Correct parsing of URLs in free-form text

fields.description: If you access a snippet by the URL https://bitbucket.org/snippets/bitbucket-user/XXXXX/snippet-title this won't be added on the recent view snippet menu. However, if you delete the name of the snippet on the URL and access only like https://bitbucket.org/snippets/bitbucket-user/XXXXX this will be added on the recent view menu.
fields.summary: Snippet menu is not being updated (BB-16121)
Ability to hide inline comment threads in pull request diffs

fields.description:
Users who try to import both Git and Hg repositories from various other hosted sites are getting these errors:

Remote Git clone failed: <type 'exceptions.RuntimeError'>: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object

Remote Mercurial clone failed: <type 'exceptions.RuntimeError'>: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object

fields.description: Remote Git clone failed: <type 'exceptions.RuntimeError'>: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object

fields.description:
On most open source projects badges for project status / build status can be seen in ReadMe.md indicating if the last build was successful or not.

Similar to this one:\\
[!https://ci.appveyor.com/api/projects/status/f645fkm37ym9ikjt?svg=true!|https://ci.appveyor.com/project/GntherFoidl/ioc]

Bitbucket Pipelines should offer this too.

fields.description: When you open the page with the list of pull requests for your project, it no longer displays the pull request number. We use those numbers as reference points so can you please put them back? I know they are still displayed in a small font once you open a specific pull request but we don't want to have to hunt through multiple pull requests to find the one we are looking for.
fields.summary: Pull request numbers no longer displayed

fields.description:
Hi,

I am trying to add an ssh key for installing private git repositories for my build script. This is a requirement for php composer to access other private packages.

First problem occured when rsa fingerprint is not added automatically so I added a script command:\\
- mkdir ~/.ssh\\
- chmod 700 ~/.ssh\\
- echo 'bitbucket.org,131.103.20.168 SOMECHARS' > ~/.ssh/known_hosts

That solved fingerprint problem. After that I tried to added an private key from command line but I need to add it securely. So I tried to add private key via environment variable but env vars removes new lines and that didn't work either.\\
- echo $PRIVATE_KEY > ~/.ssh/private_rsa\\
- chmod 600 ~/.ssh/private_rsa\\
- eval {{ssh-agent -s}}\\
- ssh-add ~/.ssh/private_rsa

Is there any way to add a private key or accessing our own private repositories somehow?
fields.summary: Accessing Private Repositories

fields.description: When adding a team member the auto fill is showing email addresses that I am not familiar with. Should it not show team members from my company only - like it does in Confluence and Jira?
fields.summary: Unknown emails showing in auto fill when adding team members

fields.description:
It could be nice if terminal escape characters were better supported, so animations made by running command line tools is displayed properly. Fx. progress bars and spinners from tools like [npm|https://www.npmjs.com] and [ava|https://github.com/avajs/ava#cli] are displayed as many lines. Also background color of text seems wrong in some cases.

Generally it could be nice if command output looked similar to your local console.
fields.summary: Better support for escape characters in Pipelines

fields.description: Set appropriate default maven/gradle (and others?) settings for heap sizes, fork counts etc. to run builds within the constraints that pipelines applies (such as 2gb ram etc).
fields.summary: Set appropriate limits for different build tools based on pipelines build limits

fields.description:
Example markdown:

{code}
text [`code`][] text

[`code`]: file.md
{code}

Expected result:

bq. text [{{code}}|file.md] text


Actual result:

bq. text [{{code}}][] text


Issue [reproduced|https://bitbucket.org/cubux/cubux-api/src/f0c3360ecd35ede3a872956e924d91b137a293f4/docs/ru/type/user.md%3Fat%3Ddevel%26fileviewer%3Dfile-view-default] at least in non-default branch. Didn't check at default branch yet.

Looks like the problem is in link reference {{[`code`]: file.md}}.

I reported the issue errornously [there|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BSERV-8806]. As i understand from comment, the problem is inconsistent.
fields.summary: Markdown link reference does not allow code

fields.description: I realise this is not currently supported. Is there a workaround for it such as using a third party service or something like that? Are there any plans to support this in the future perhaps with docker in docker support?
fields.summary: Building and pushing Docker images

fields.description:
Occassionally, I've noticed that the code showing changes in a pull request is missing a curly brace that is actually in the code.  The line just after also does not appear indented correctly.  Case in point:

!2253910901-missing_curly_in_pr.png|thumbnail!

There _is_ a curly brace on line 2809 (old line 2812).  My colleague put a comment on that line and the emailed version of the code shows the curly brace:

!1391447178-curly_brace_in_email.png|thumbnail!

Note also that the indent on the following line is fixed (line 2811 (old line 2814)).  Also note that even without the comment on the code on that line, the curly brace was not visible.

This bug can be confusing when reviewing a pull request.  Please fix this.
fields.summary: Sometimes a curly brace will be missing in the pull request code snippets

fields.description:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/repository-resource-423626331.html

Just a simple "project" property would be enough in the POST request, please implement this asap.
fields.summary: Assign repository to a project using the API

fields.description:
We have Bitbucket installed on an internal server, and I was preparing to populate a repo we set up on that server.

From another server inside the network (where the files we want to track are), I run the commands listed on on the empty repo page. I run into issues when running "git push origin master"...output is: "fatal: unable to access 'http://myusername@bitbucketservername/pathtorepository.git': Failed to connect to bitbucketservername port 80: Timed out"

I am able to ping bitbucketservername, so I'm unsure where the hang up is.

I ran a test last week on a different repo with files on my local computer, and it worked perfectly, including a post-receive hook to automatically deploy files to the server that contains the files for the operation I tried to run today. This says to me it's some kind of network issue, but am wondering if this sort of thing has been seen before, and if there's something with the remote Bitbucket asks me to use that might be causing trouble.

Thanks!
fields.summary: git push timing out

fields.description:
This is already available in Bamboo/Bitbucket. Would be perfect if this would also be implemented for Pipelines:

"Select this option to stop pull requests from being merged if they have any unsuccessful builds. For a pull request, this checks builds that run against the latest commit on the source branch.\\
You must also specify a minimum number of builds - the pull request will not be able to be merged until at least this many builds have completed. Ideally, you should set this to the number of different builds that are configured to run against the branches in your repository."
fields.summary: Requires a minimum number of successful builds

BCLOUD-5689

_(answer from @mbertrand80 It would be nice to support this, but it would require a big overhaul of our diff viewing to make sure the user experience is great, which we don't plan on doing anytime soon )_

Many have asked this but have been unheard ( @shelajev @mcdonald-austin  @rbarbalace @mkorolyov @karuturi @thobach @kokesh @roberto_sc  @ktopham @puruka and others )

I am an user from Talentsoft, a client of yours, and I am not the only one in need of this functionality at talentsoft!

Regards,\\
Eduardo HENAO

fields.description:
Hi, I want to use bitbucket's webhook service to implement a custom deployment progress.

When a branch named {{daily/1.0.1}} is created or new commit pushed into this branch, my server will upload the static files in {{/build}} to {{/daily/1.0.1/}} in Amazon S3.

When a tag named {{publish/1.0.1}} is created, my server will upload the static files in {{/publish/1.0.1}} in Amazon S3

Or did I miss something?

Pipeline needs similar features

fields.description:
Maybe I am wrong, but I would think someone looking at logs wants to diagnose/troubleshoot, and would be most interest in the last things that happned,  not the start.

To that end its annoying to download the entire raw logs to  see the last 20 lines I need to understand the failure.  It would be nice to just have it say "download to see all lines, here;s the last 500"
fields.summary: Pipelines: When log exceeds limit, consider showing last XXX lines instead of first XXX lines

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, a merge commit is marked as MERGE WITH CONFLICTS only if the word 'Conflicts:', with the colon, is included in the commit message, at the beginning of the row:

!2908237132-Screenshot%20from%202016-05-27%2016-24-04.png|thumbnail!

Many Git clients generate automatically a commit message like the following for merge commits with conflicts:

{code}
Merged v60-hotfixes into master

# Conflicts:
#   foo.php
#   bar.php
#   foobar.php
{code}

Merge commits with extra characters before {{Conflicts:}} are *not* highlighted by Bitbucket. They look like regular merge commits:

!690512446-Screenshot%20from%202016-05-27%2016-31-55.png|thumbnail!

h3. Suggested Solution
Label a merge commit as MERGE WITH CONFLICTS if it includes the word 'Conflicts:' anywhere in the commit message
fields.summary: Mark as MERGE WITH CONFLICTS all merge commits that include the word 'Conflicts:'

fields.description: This will allow builds access to private resources for running integration tests, etc.
fields.summary: Allow customers to connect the pipelines builds to their own VPN server

fields.description:
Builds that use a secure random number generator hang or take a long time to complete because the available entropy is limited on the host so it takes a long time to secure a random number.

One option is to use /dev/urandom to generate pseudo-random data to allow the build to complete. This workaround should be documented so that users know that pipelines uses a pseudo-random number generator in place of a secure one.
fields.summary: Support for builds that require a secure random number generator by using /dev/urandom to generate a pseudo-random number instead

fields.description:
At the moment all the steps are limited to a list of commands that can be run. While useful, a more powerful solution would be to allow other types of scripts. An example of this would be an AWS Lambda step where you only have to provide your settings and everything else is already done for you. Currently you need to go through several steps, which includes adding a script to your repository, and that's not an optimal solution.

An example of how this works in a different CI tool is this step that I created for [Lambda deployments|https://github.com/ArjenSchwarz/wercker-step-deploy-lambda]. Especially the ability to share steps like this across your projects (or with other people), would make Pipelines even more powerful.

Obviously, this would depend on BCLOUD-12750
fields.summary: Allow more capable steps that can be reused

fields.description:
Currently it's only possible to have a single step defined for default or a branch. The ability to have multiple steps would allow the YAML file to be far more readable as the commands would be grouped by functionality. For example:

{code}
#!yaml
image: golang
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        script:
          - mkdir -p /go/src/github.com/ArjenSchwarz/aqua
          - mv * /go/src/github.com/ArjenSchwarz/aqua
          - apt-get update
          - apt-get install -y zip
          - cd /go/src/github.com/ArjenSchwarz/aqua
          - go get -t ./...
          - go test ./...
          - GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 go build -a -ldflags '-s' -o binary
          - curl -v -u $BB_ACCESS -X POST https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/$BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER/$BITBUCKET_REPO_SLUG/downloads/ -F files=@binary
{code}

Could be displayed as the below instead, which makes it a lot more obvious what everything is for.

{code}
#!yaml
image: golang
pipelines:
  default:
    - prepare:
        script:
          - mkdir -p /go/src/github.com/ArjenSchwarz/aqua
          - mv * /go/src/github.com/ArjenSchwarz/aqua
          - apt-get update
          - apt-get install -y zip
          - cd /go/src/github.com/ArjenSchwarz/aqua
     - test:
         script:
          - go get -t ./...
          - go test ./...
     - build:
        script:
          - GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 go build -a -ldflags '-s' -o binary
      - deploy:
         script:
          - curl -v -u $BB_ACCESS -X POST https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/$BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER/$BITBUCKET_REPO_SLUG/downloads/ -F files=@binary
{code}
fields.summary: Allow multiple steps

fields.description:
CI steps can grow quickly, and when there are tasks that need to be done on all branches it would be better if you don't have to repeat them in the YAML file as that leads to potential problems. What I mean is probably best shown with an example:

You have a project and you want to run certain tests on all branches: lint checks, unit tests, and code quality, and maybe you need to compile it as well. This involves several commands to be run. In addition you have a staging branch that needs to automatically deploy for your QA team, and a master branch that needs to be deployed to your production environment.

With the current situation this means you have to write out all of the build steps for default as well as for the master and staging branches. It would be far better if there was a way to define the test/compile steps as global or shared steps that need to run for every branch. Maybe as part of a all: section or a flag for branches to (optionally) inherit from default.
fields.summary: Inheritance/extending of steps

fields.description:
It would be powerful if Bitbucket would allow Pipelines to be executed as a task in a customer's EC2 Container Service (ECS) cluster. This would allow customers to:

* Access private resources in their VPC such as a private package repository.
* Use IAM roles (e.g. not disclose their AWS secret keys to you).
* Scale their own build fleets.

I would imagine the flow would go something like this:

* The customer creates a predefined IAM role (copy and paste from the documentation) that allows the following permissions: RegisterTaskDefinition, RunTask, StopTask, and ListTasks (possibly more).
* The Customer than grants the Bitbucket AWS account the STS AssumeRole permission.
* The Customer configures their ECS Integration by specifying the cluster name, CPU/memory limits, etc...
* When starting a pipeline you would call the RegisterTaskDefinition API (if the TaskDefinition doesn't already exist) and run the task.

Thanks,\\
Adam
fields.summary: Run build on customer's ECS/Kube/VPC

fields.description:
Hi,

I was trying to use Pipelines, I followed the documentation however my created pipeline definition doesn't seem to be picked up. I checked existing issues with the "Pipelines" component, however I couldn't find anything similar hence I'm raising this issue.

Repo: https://bitbucket.org/winnovations/jakworkspace\\
Pipeline: https://bitbucket.org/winnovations/jakworkspace/addon/pipelines/home#!/

Thanks,\\
Adam

fields.description:

This is especially important if we forward a public URL to the project home page. Currently there's just a bunch of repository links, with nothing to tell the public what the project is about.

P.S. Shouldn't "Project" be one of the available components in this issue tracker?

fields.description:
I'm new to Docker, and to Pipelines, but we're investing heavily in a new app that is being built from the ground up on ASP.NET Core (RC2, at the moment)

I suggest you add an example to the "getting started" on how to use Pipelines with .NET Core projects. There's a docker image available named microsoft/dotnet that works great (see [here|http://davevde.github.io/using-bitbucket-pipelines-with-aspnet-core/] ) but it lacks support for Node.

fields.description: One of the great features of Bamboo was the tracking the history of JUnit (xUnit) tests - and the quarantining, etc.  We need that in Pipelines too.

fields.description:
We need to run nightly builds, separate from commits in Pipelines.

We do this because we want to run a versions update to pick up our latest releases of internal libraries to ensure that nothing is broken.  Since the dependencies are typically in a different git repo, we need to run this nightly (or on some schedule) to go check the artifact repository (nexus) for new releases of those libraries.
fields.summary: Add scheduled builds to Pipelines

fields.description:
###Summary###\\
When the Author of a Pull Request(PR) deleted the Bitbucket account, the PR unable to view the Reviewers and the Author of the PR in the page.

It also breaks the bitbucket.org homepage of the PR reviewers with the following error in console:

{code}
Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'username' of null
    at load-pull-requests.js:18
    at Array.filter (<anonymous>)
    at t.transformPullRequest (load-pull-requests.js:16)
    at Array.map (<anonymous>)
    at load-pull-requests.js:35
    at spread.js?3c41:25
    at <anonymous>
{code}

###Steps to Reproduce###

# Log in to _Account A_
# Create a Pull Request with _Account B_ as reviewer
# Go to *Bitbucket Settings>Delete Account* to delete _Account A_
# Log in to _Account B_ to view the Pull Request

###Expected Results###\\
Before account deleted:

!3441091348-PR.PNG|thumbnail!

After account deleted

!3626639609-PR2.PNG|thumbnail! !281273563-PR1.PNG|thumbnail!

###Actual Results###\\
To be able to view who is the Author and Reviewer of the Pull request

###Notes###\\
When the Author access permission is revoked from the repository, the Pull Request still able to show the information regarding the Author and Reviewer.
fields.summary: Unable to view Pull Request data (Author and Reviewers) after the Author's account is deleted (BB-16117)

fields.description:
I don`t see firstName and lastName payload return from v2 api

https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/user-endpoint-2-0-744527199.html

while User API for V1 has them in payload

username	The name associated with the account.\\
first_name	The first name associated with account.\\
last_name	The last name associated with the account. For a team account, this value is always empty.\\
avatar	An avatar associated with the account.\\
resource_uri	The account resource identifier.
fields.summary: Missing firstname lastname from v2 user api

fields.description:
When I receive a Pull Request, I create a new branch in my repo, go to the other repo to edit the PR for it to merge into that new branch, then go back to the PR in my repo, and make the merge (all from BitBucket).\\
I then check it out on my local dev, and then choose to approve (and merge to develop) or refuse (and delete the branch) the PR.\\
It would be nice, on the PR's page, to have a button [Merge in new branch], maybe with the ability to select the branch from which to base the newly created branch.\\
Creating a new branch from here would save some time and also allow auto-merge with conflicts (the conflicts being solved later, when checking out the branch locally).\\
Would this also help others, or am I complicating something that is done in a simple but different way?
fields.summary: Merge Pull Requests into newly created branchs

If this isn't feasible, can you please make the project field optional when creating a new repository as we don't want to use this feature with the current restraints.

fields.description: Although I marked this as bug, I don't know if this is the intended behavior or not, but if I try to get a file from downloads section and I add an Authorization header to the request, I get an error: h3. Request: {code} #!text GET /2.0/repositories/[REDACTED]/[REDACTED]/downloads/tada.txt HTTP/1.1 Host: api.bitbucket.org Authorization: Bearer [REDACTED] {code} h3. Response {code} #!xml InvalidArgument Only one auth mechanism allowed; only the X-Amz-Algorithm query parameter, Signature query string parameter or the Authorization header should be specified Authorization Bearer [REDACTED] 21F7FF9210ABB039 i+Nr+46+N6G6XVv+DaES9/VJJiFEBkJx6cC51BiJK4fRIGV6EDxmO3NNtmLU2jx7gOeTskpKlxM= {code} If I use the same token as query parameter, everything works as expected: h3. Request {code} #!text GET /2.0/repositories/[REDACTED]/[REDACTED]/downloads/tada.txt?access_token=[REDACTED] HTTP/1.1 Host: api.bitbucket.org {code} h3. Response {code} #!text Accept-Ranges →bytes Content-Disposition →attachment; filename="tada.txt" Content-Length →12 Content-Type →text/plain Date →Mon, 23 May 2016 11:25:42 GMT ETag →"9589f334c6f4987fc5ddb8e0ac1c096b" Last-Modified →Mon, 23 May 2016 10:07:23 GMT Server →AmazonS3 x-amz-id-2 →OEkORy7DeZyzzzLhNHrSgI2+wINxpUFuXmY25IRljT5qdBW2+RV7z6vCQOCChNyXGtDPmoEuEPc= x-amz-request-id →4A875ED488118153 x-amz-version-id →n1aO3GXGH.OiTlDa.sTftqJKRxiVOx0U {code}
fields.summary: Error when trying to get a specific file from downloads section with Authorization header.

fields.description:
I imported the Linux repo from https://github.com/torvalds/linux.git via the Bitbucket UI.

SSH clone worked fine.\\
HTTP clone times outs within 1m10s with no other output.

{code}
71% 2016-05-22 09:34:35 ☆  mbp in /tmp/linuxhttp
± |master ✓| → git fetch --progress https://mstudman@bitbucket.org/<omitted>/linux.git
error: RPC failed; result=52, HTTP code = 0
fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly

71% 2016-05-22 09:35:46 ☆  map in /tmp/linuxhttp
{code}

Getting a support engineer to do a remote GC on the repo fixes the problem - HTTP clone succeeds.

{code}
± |master ✓| → git fetch --progress https://mstudman@bitbucket.org/<omitted>/linux.git
remote: Counting objects: 4691121, done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (716308/716308), done.
...
{code}

Note that the repo size is roughly the same before and after the GC. If I had to guess, I'd suggest Django kills the request because there's absolutely no output for too long at the start of the request. Why there is no output when SSH cloning/fetching starts outputting progress after 5-10s is something you will need to investigate.

BTW *this problem is repeatable* - just import from Linux on github and attempt to clone via HTTP
fields.summary: Initially imported repo fails on fetch over HTTP (BB-16097)

fields.description:
Customer's request:

None of the cloud addons offer support for things such as setting constraints on commit.

Specifically I'm looking to automatically reject commits with no comments. From the current documentation the only way I'd be able to do this on bitbucket cloud would be to set all branches for code review of sorts, this would be problematic and a complete time sink for our team.

To have a feature to set constraints on commit will be really helpful and help save a lot of time.
fields.summary: Customer Request: Have a feature to set constraints on commit.

fields.description:
Customer's request:

I recently had a potential security risk.

I unintentionally commited a file with my DBcredentials.\\
My app design flaw made the sensitive data visible in a error log - publicly available.

Please take a look at this discussion\\
https://github.com/laravel/framework/issues/13647

You should design a security measure - an option which refuses a commmit if it contains certain files.

Best would be a scanner which searches content of files being committed for API keys, passwords, etc.
fields.summary: Customer Request: Have an option which refuses a commmit if it contains certain files.
Printing of MarkDown files as PDF or printable format.

fields.description: It would be nice to store my javadoc files in the wiki of my project next to my other documentation
fields.summary: Add the possibility to add HTML files in bitbucket wiki

fields.description:
Hi,

I noticed in your Branch Management, you are able to control the push-level permissions. We need to be able to control the pull-level or read permissions on a branch.

Our scenario:\\
We have 2 bitbucket users U1, U2, and each one has a respective branch B1, B2. The code base is shared from the default branch, but there are specifics and sensitive information in B1 that shouldn't be shared with U2, and vise-versa.

I'd prefer not to fork and do a massive cleanup, and keep things in the same repo.

Tech support forwarded me here to make a feature request.

Thanks,

Jason H.
fields.summary: Branch Management: branch level read-access permissions

# Hit preview

###Expected Results###\\
!2941213972-Textile%20Expected.PNG|thumbnail!

###Actual Results###\\

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
After entering issue details, the user needs to mouse over the *Create Issue* button and click to create an issue.

h3. Suggested Solution
To include a _Ctrl+Enter_ keyboard shortcut that would allow the user to create an issue faster.

_Ctrl+Enter_ is currently uses as _Submit your comment_ but it will be best that user able to use it to Create an issue too.
fields.summary: Customer Request : Keyboard shortcut (Ctrl+Enter) to submit an Issue in the Create Issue Page (BB-16119)

fields.description:
When merging pull requests that are for a different branch than master, the pull requests are not resolved when the merged changes are pushed to bitbucket.

The overview tab on the pull request still shows the original diff but the commits tab is empty ("There are no changes"). It also shows no conflicts in the overview tab.

When resolving PRs to master locally and pushing to master the PRs are automatically resolved.
fields.summary: Pull requests to other branches than master do not get automatically resolved after push
Feature Request: open all "related issues" in JIRA
software architecture

fields.description:
Currently the invitation link will only work if the user has yet to register a Bitbucket account. This shouldn't be the case - all users should be able to accept the invitation regardless if they have an account or not, with:

* users that have yet to have an account to be lead to registration page.
* users that have an account to be lead immediately to the team account page.
fields.summary: Accepting an invitation link leads to a 500 error if user has an existing account. (BB-16099)

I am getting a wrong repo size of 1.2 Gb on the repo.\\
The repo size before I believe was 550 Mb, so I did a clean with BFG repo cleaner.\\
But today suddenly the repo looks to have 1.2Gb size.\\
Although when I do "git count-objects -v -H" I'm getting this:

count: 13\\
size: 80.00 KiB\\
in-pack: 16314\\
packs: 1\\
size-pack: 259.45 MiB\\
prune-packable: 0\\
garbage: 0\\
size-garbage: 0 bytes

I'm not sure how to fix this issue. The strange thing is when I actually download the entire repo, the size is only 120.6 Mb. Although I've seen from other issues that this is something Bitbucket support can fix on their side. So hopefully you can help me also with this issue.

fields.description:
Currently, when creating a pull request from a branch that includes the issue key, the default title removes the dash, which means linking back to the issue is not possible without editing the title:

For example:

!3699556421-Screen%20Shot%202016-05-17%20at%204.33.57%20PM.png|thumbnail!

The branch name 'TES-1-test-bug' defaults to 'Tes 1 test bug'

Pull request default titles should keep the dash to keep the issue key linked on the title.
fields.summary: Customer request: Default pull request title should display issue key when created from a branch that includes an issue key

fields.description:
Old and outdated pull request comments aren't being marked as such. This happens inconsistently and I can't determine the cause.

Example 1: https://bitbucket.org/canstar-dev/canstar_widgets/pull-requests/250/18776-managed-funds-and-etfs/diff#comment-18276855

Example 2: All comments in this file should be outdated: https://bitbucket.org/canstar-dev/canstar_widgets/pull-requests/250/18776-managed-funds-and-etfs/diff#chg-web/assets/js/libraries/Transforms.coffee

Example 3: All comments in this PR: https://bitbucket.org/canstar-dev/canstar_widgets/pull-requests/261/19434-credit-cards-phase-2/diff

As an aside, the number of comments displayed in the file view of example 2 does not match the number of comments shown in the actual file.
fields.summary: Pull request comments aren't being marked as outdated
